author: NA
title: RM1.37mil worth of fines issued for smoking | The Star
text:
PUTRAJAYA: Over 93% of compound notices issued since the enforcement of the Control of Smoking Products for Public Health Act 2024 (Act 852) were for smoking in prohibited areas, says the Health Minister.
Datuk Seri Dr Dzulkefly Ahmad said the ministry has issued 5,642 notices amounting to RM1.37mil in compounds from Oct 1 to Dec 17.
Out of that, he said 5,271 notices fell under Section 16(2) for smoking in prohibited areas.
Meanwhile, 193 notices were issued under Section 17(1) for offences involving underage individuals smoking or using tobacco products, he said.
To bolster enforcement efforts under the Act, Dzulkefly said the launch of the JomLapor online platform is aimed at achieving a smoke-free Malaysia by 2040.
“JomLapor, rolled out on Wednesday, has already received 135 complaints. All reports are anonymous to ensure the safety of informants,” Dzulkefly said during the platform’s official launch yesterday, Bernama reported.
He said the platform is designed to encourage public cooperation in maintaining smoke-free environments, especially in spaces frequented by senior citizens, pregnant women and children.
Separately, he said the ministry received 13,000 complaints regarding smoking offences in public places via WhatsApp this year.
Dzulkefly reiterated the government’s firm stance on enforcing Act 852, emphasising equal treatment under the law.
“There are no double standards in the Madani government. For instance, the Foreign Minister (Datuk Seri Mohamad Hasan) made a mistake, accepted the compound issued and paid it. That’s the spirit we want to see,” he said.
Developed in collaboration with non-governmental organisations and professional bodies, JomLapor strengthens enforcement against violations such as advertising, promotion or sponsorship of tobacco products, as well as sales in educational institutions or marketplaces, online platforms and vending machines.

author: Carlos Castellanos
title: Aldo Posas habla de su nueva faceta y revela por qué no triunfó como portero: "Llegaba alcoholizado al entrenamiento"
text: "El momento más duro fue cuando me entregaron a mi papá envuelto en una sábana como cualquier cosa", recuerda con dolor al hablar de la partida de Roy: su papá, el forjador de sus pasos, el consejero al que no escuchó para triunfar como cuidapalos.Aldo, gracias por esta charla. ¿Qué recuerdos tienes de tu infancia? La verdad que las fajeadas de mi mamá, las orejeadas, porque nos íbamos a escondidas con Roy (hermano y exdefensa de Motagua, entre otros clubes) a jugar al campo y, cuando regresábamos, ya venían los fajazos y las hincadas.¿Era más dura tu mamá que Roy? Claro, era más dura mi mamá que mi papá. Nos castigaba por todo y por nada, pero le agradecemos porque gracias a ella creo que nosotros somos excelentes personas. Nos tocaba sufrir a nuestra madre porque mi papá siempre salía a estar dirigiendo en equipos o selecciones.¿Cómo valoras tu paso por Motagua? Me trataron bien y soy Motagua de corazón, pero con mis actos yo nunca hice cosas bien para poder debutar. Tenía terribles condiciones, pero yo andaba en otras cosas, andaba en la vida loca. Fui a otros equipos y ahí sí logré debutar en Liga Nacional.Cuando me decís que estabas en tu vida loca, ¿en qué fallaste? Sí, falta de madurez, también el alcohol a temprana edad. Andábamos en una juventud de bastante locura, pero eso queda de experiencia. Me costó poder cambiar esa vida que yo llevaba de juventud, una vida bastante loca de alcoholismo. Busqué de Dios hace seis años y ahí estoy ya establecido en las cosas de Él. ¿Se puede decir que el alcohol prácticamente cortó tu carrera?Así es, el alcohol creo que cortó mi carrera porque no era una persona seria, una persona que estaba comprometida con mi trabajo. Muchas veces llegué alcoholizado al entrenamiento, con una gran goma, pero nunca me notaron.

author: Importer
title: Saudi Arabia and France Strengthen Health Cooperation Through Strategic Agreements in Biotech and Digital Health | finanzen.net
text:
Home Aktien Saudi Arabia and France Strengthen Health Cooperation Through Strategic Agreements in Biotech and Digital Health Saudi Arabia and France Strengthen Health Cooperation Through Strategic Agreements in Biotech and Digital Health 17.04.25 00:03 Uhr Werbung PARIS , April 16, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- On the second day of an official visit to France , His Excellency Fahad Abdulrahman AlJalajel , Minister of Health of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia , held bilateral meetings with senior French officials including Minister for Labour, Health, Solidarity and Families Catherine Vautrin, Minister for Health and Access to Care Yannick Neuder and Laurent Saint-Martin , Minister Delegate for Foreign Trade and French Nationals Abroad.
Discussions focused on strengthening cooperation in health innovation, research, workforce development, investment promotion, and supply chain resilience, aligned with the Kingdom's Vision 2030 Health Sector Transformation.
A highlight of the visit was the signing of several agreements, witnessed by Their Excellencies, designed to strengthen and expand the health partnership between Saudi Arabia and France . The first between Seha Virtual Hospital and Gustave Roussy aims to enhance cancer care and digital health through AI-powered telemedicine.
Another, signed between the Health Holding Company (HHC) and France Biotech, focuses on accelerating the development of the Health Tech and Life Sciences ecosystems in both countries by supporting healthcare startups and promoting the integration of innovative technologies.
A third agreement, between the Saudi Red Crescent Authority and Assistance publique-hôpitaux de Paris , will strengthen cooperation in Emergency Medical Services, including joint training, knowledge exchange, and best practices in emergency response.
His Excellency Minister Aljalajel stated: "I welcome the strengthening of these collaborative ties with France's leading institutions, which reflect our commitment to advancing excellence and innovation across the health sector. These partnerships not only strengthen international ties but also position the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia as a dynamic and innovation-friendly ecosystem - one that is actively attracting global innovators and creating significant opportunities for transformative impact within our evolving healthcare landscape. They represent an important step forward in achieving the goals of Vision 2030, as we continue to transform our health system to deliver world-class care and foster a thriving life sciences sector."
The Minister's three-day visit to Paris and Lyon demonstrates the shared commitment of Saudi Arabia and France to enhance healthcare services and innovation, while further strengthening their bilateral relationship in support of global health goals.
Photo - https://mma.prnewswire.com/media/2666968/Ministry_of_Health_Saudi_Arabia.jpg

author: Daniel Vila Nova
title: Confira os memes da derrota do Corinthians nas quartas de final da Copa do Brasil
text: Confira os memes da derrota do Corinthians nas quartas de final da Copa do Brasil Nas redes sociais, torcedores alvinegros brincam e dizem que resultado da partida pode influenciar o corintiano Alexandre de Moraes O [Corinthians](https://www.terra.com.br/esportes/corinthians/) foi derrotado pelo [Juventude](https://www.terra.com.br/esportes/juventude/) na noite desta quinta-feira, dia 29 de agosto, em jogo válido pelas quartas de final Copa do Brasil. No estádio Alfredo Jaconi, em Caxias do Sul, a equipe gaúcha fez 2 a 1 e saiu com a vantagem na partida de ida do confronto. [Assine Amazon Prime e os primeiros 30 dias são pagos pelo Terra] Nas redes sociais, a torcida corintiana lamentou a derrota e brincou com a situação atual do clube. No X, o antigo Twitter, as principais piadas envolveram o ministro do Supremo Tribunal Federal (STF) Alexandre de Moraes, que é corintiano, e sua decisão de bloquear a plataforma no Brasil. Para muitos, o resultado do jogo poderia influenciar o futuro da rede social no País. Veja os melhores memes da derrota: Tava pensando aqui Twitter vai acabar as 20:07 hoje, o jogo do Corinthians começa às 20:00. Qual a chance do último tweet do Corinthians no twitter ser "Gol deles." ? — Cortinas, o time do roubo (@cortinasdoroubo)[August 29, 2024] Twitter não passa de hoje — William Castro (@William_Castro)[https://t.co/RoVJ4dKnVN][pic.twitter.com/hFUVj5EPP1][August 30, 2024] Twitter vai cair às 20:07 Corinthians caiu em 2007 — Cortinas Rage Comics 22/45 (@sccpragecomics)[pic.twitter.com/z8vLqvEisj][August 29, 2024] xandão derrubando o twitter para os rivais não zuarem mais o corinthians, muito corinthiano ele — Museu de memes do Corinthians (@museu_sccp)[pic.twitter.com/AkVYTMbIra][August 29, 2024] "A derrota nos fortalece" Os jogadores do Corinthians chegando no treino após mais um jogo: — MANUAL DO JOGADOR RUIM (@oficialmanualjr)[pic.twitter.com/MWORMLaekY][August 30, 2024] — Cavalinho do Corinthians (@sccpcavalo)[August 30, 2024] — Museu de memes do Corinthians (@museu_sccp)[August 30, 2024] *Se bater o ônibus, tem que vencer uma partida* Corinthians: — MANUAL DO JOGADOR RUIM (@oficialmanualjr)[pic.twitter.com/nH5OYp1Drs][August 30, 2024]

author: Jacky
title: From Purple Vegetables To 'climate Change Foods' Like Figs And Almonds, Experts Predict Top Gardening Trends For 2024 » WhatsNew2Day
text: Purple vegetables and ‘climate-changing foods’ such as figs and almonds will be among the top gardening trends for 2024. Houseplants and wildflowers are also likely to be in vogue, according to the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) in London. The charity’s predictions for the year ahead are based on current trends and consultations with its advisers and experts. Purple foods are very popular among the health-conscious because they contain anthocyanins, antioxidants that reduce inflammation in the body. Some studies suggest that they can reduce the risk of cardiovascular problems and improve thinking skills in older people. Purple foods are very popular among health-conscious people because they contain anthocyanins that reduce inflammation. In the photo, piles of purple sweet potatoes at the vegetable market. Now people are looking beyond superfood fruits, such as blueberries, to purple vegetables, and there are new varieties that are easier to grow and avoid previous problems such as lack of fruit and limited “purple color”, especially after of cooking. Predicting that purple vegetables will be a gardening fad for next year, the RHS says: “Gardeners and chefs can look forward to purple carrots, cauliflower, broccoli, tomatoes, peas, radishes, green beans and lettuce.” Britain’s recent hot, dry summers are ideal for vines, figs, almonds, apricots, melons and watermelons, and peaches or nectarines, according to gardening experts. But they warn that climate change may make it difficult for growing fruits that need refrigeration during winter, such as blackcurrants, apples and pears. However, many of the UK’s 30 million gardeners will focus on making gardens resilient to unusual weather conditions and improving plant health in 2024, the RHS predicts. Some people are adopting “survival gardens,” such as those that use seed varieties adapted to local climates. Based on the highest number of queries the RHS has received in 2023 (115,000), it also says there has been an increase in urban gardeners, often without a garden of their own, growing plants in pots, on balconies and indoors, for example. example using terrariums. Houseplants and wildflowers are likely to become increasingly fashionable as people have less outdoor space for gardening. Enthusiasts want to fill every corner of their homes with tropical-looking plants and orchids that create a “jungle” look, and their favorite houseplants, such as the succulent known as “donkey’s tail”, Epipremnum and old favorites such as the decorative thread of hearts. plant and spider plant. Creating a Mediterranean look by growing citrus plants is increasingly popular, and inquiries to the RHS about it have increased by 22 per cent. Clare Matterson, RHS chief executive, said: “I am excited to see growing interest in gardening in urban areas. ‘My first garden was in a small flat in Brixton, London. Through this small space, I was able to put my hands in the dirt, connect with the seasons, and enjoy growing flowers and vegetables. “At RHS we want to open up gardening to everyone, everywhere.” The RHS Gardening Advice service and website continues to see notable growth in ‘grow your own’ enquiries, with gardeners happy to accept lower yields to look after their plots in a more environmentally friendly way, with less irrigation, use of mulch to retain rainwater, storage of rainwater and abandonment of fertilizers. The most popular produce grown at home is tomatoes, followed by cucumbers, zucchini, chili peppers and green beans. There is also interest in backyard fruit varieties such as dwarf raspberries, blackberries and blackberries. Meanwhile, people continue to embrace wildflowers, from non-native meadows in gardens to wildflower borders with plants such as alexander, meadowsweet and Welsh poppy. Even plants traditionally seen as “unwanted weeds,” such as robert weed and plantain, are becoming popular; Parsley is now a desirable border plant and dandelions are recognized as key to providing food for bees in early spring. Gardeners appear increasingly in tune with nature, with inquiries to the RHS on wildlife-friendly gardening increasing by more than 28 per cent in 2023, and many people choosing to let their grass grow long to support pollinating insects. , invertebrates and the wildlife that depend on it. them. There is interest in building insect hotels, sourcing pollinator-friendly plants, leaving dead wood in the garden and introducing even small aquatic features to benefit wildlife. In 2024, when the peat compost ban for hobby gardeners comes into force, people will make the most of home composting opportunities and look for sustainable alternatives. The 20 Costliest Climate Disasters of 2023 – REVEALED In 2023, no corner of the world was spared from disastrous climate phenomena that suffered droughts, floods, forest fires and tropical storms. A new report reveals the 20 most financially costly climate disasters of the year, and all six of the world’s populated continents are on the list. At the top are the shocking Hawaii wildfires in August, which killed at least 100 people and cost more than $4,000 per person in damage. Also included are the storms in Guam in May – which cost almost $1,500 per inhabitant –, the floods in New Zealand, the droughts in Spain and the forest fires in Chile. Read more
